intro: Quercus avellanoides, commonly known as the Mexican chestnut oak, is a deciduous tree native to central Mexico. It belongs to the Fagaceae family, which includes oaks, beeches, and chestnuts. The plant is characterized by its elliptical leaves with a serrated margin and its production of small, chestnut-like acorns. It typically grows in dry to moist forests and thrives in well-drained soils. The botanical features of Quercus avellanoides make it an important species for ecological studies and conservation efforts in its native habitat.
